response.answer_text: No, and nor should it. We’re witnessing a clear shift in the United States as a whole - not because anything has changed, as such, but rather because the shakey reality of the nation’s status quo has been exposed as a front. Prior to Trump, the Presidency and control of Congress would switch quite routinely between the two political parties, and this was an accepted thing. Even when you opposed the government in power, it was largely done in a civil fashion. Peaceful protests, reasonable rhetoric, engaging dialogue between the two, largely on policy rather than personality. What we’re now seeing is a US population split between two narratives: the reality, and the fact that the United States falls far short of the mark on far too many fronts; and then the false narrative, wherein the United States is heralded as the greatest nation on the planet, peaceful, prosperous, nothing untoward going on. Personally, I wish the false narrative was the same as reality, but alas… Trump has exposed a lot of issues within the States. An anti-intellectual segment of the population that has a huge amount of anger, and that feels disenfranchised…even when their guy is in the Oval Office. They feel that the United States is under attack from people who want to change it - not recognising that change and growth are built into the very foundations. The United States isn’t a conservative, regressive nation: it is and always has been a liberal one. Obtaining independence and establishing a democratic nation on constitutional foundations was a liberal act. Ending slavery was a liberal act. The Civil Rights movement…a liberal act. Unfortunately, what we’re truthfully seeing now is that the Civil War never really ended: it just moved from the battlefield and into politics, on an ideological front. The whole “One Nation Under God” is really two nations: one, liberal and progressive, the other, conservative and regressive, preferring a ‘Golden Age’ of America that never really existed, but that would again if but for liberal, immigrants, non-Christians, foreigners and a whole list of other people. I genuinely think we’re seeing that split more clearly now than we did during the Civil War: we see one group desiring an authoritarian state, one strong individual in control, a Christian nation where abortion and LGBQT+ are limited or outlawed, where the strength of the nation is built upon her military might and her ability to limit who may and may not be called American. It’s evident enough that this state should be one of white privilege and supremacy, and there’s clearly some desire to see black Americans relegated to the same status as immigrants and other foreigners: useful, but not really Americans. How do you walk that back, as a nation? Biden supplanting Trump by winning the election only removes the loudspeaker announcing these feelings - it doesn’t change them, nor remove them. Nothing is technically improved - we just see those tensions more muted once again, but they’ll still be there. And now that Trump has given them license…do we see them return to a muted state, or are we at the point where something’s got to give? I think the time of a more civil United States has ended. This either needs to change outright, or we genuinely need to witness the break-up of the Union, because it’s clear enough that bridging the divide might well be beyond the capacity of any American to accomplish now. Biden will be a band-aid, but I can’t see him healing the wounds. Of course that’s better than Trump, who would exacerbate the injuries until the nation just bleeds out…but the problem isn’t going to be so easily resolved. That resentment, that lingering desire to see a different nation than the one that actually exists…that’s not going away. So, no, I don’t see things going ‘back to normal’. How can they? We’ve come to recognise that one significant segment of the population genuinely thinks that the other exists to oppress them, and ironically, that same segment has little concern about doing exactly that to everyone else in order to protect themselves. Lincoln said it best: "A house divided against itself cannot stand." I believe this government cannot endure, permanently half slave and half free. I do not expect the Union to be dissolved -- I do not expect the house to fall -- but I do expect it will cease to be divided. It will become all one thing or all the other. Well, he was right that a house divided cannot stand, but he was wrong to imagine that the war would end with singular will. It hasn’t ceased to be divided: the divisions just went underground, simmering, but existent. That’s now no longer the case: we can see the divisions for what they are, and it’s becoming more and more apparent that the house cannot stand. We can’t have a nation perpetually at war with itself. But it’s starting to look like that’s what we’ve got.
